intro: Filix-mas thelypteris var. pubescens, commonly known as the hairy male fern, is a variant of the male fern species characterized by its distinctive hairy fronds. It is a fern belonging to the family Dryopteridaceae, known for its intricate and delicate leaf structures. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its fronds are bi- or tri-pinnate, with a serrated or lobed margin. The spore-bearing structures, or sori, are located on the underside of the fronds, contributing to its reproductive strategy.
